field_edited_text.value:
Pol icy:
Complete the approved Federal 50’
project as rapidly as possible.

.“

Policy:

The Maryland Port Administration,
working with other state agencies,
federal and local governments
should develop a comprehensive
plan for the disposal and
management of dredge materials
generated from both public and
private sector projects in Maryland
waters over the next 20 years.

The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
recommended in June, 1969, that channels
in the harbor be deepened to 50 feet to
accommodate the ever-larger bulk carriers
which transport such sizable volumes of
commodities to and from the Port. Cur-
rently most bulk goods, coal, iron ore, grain
and petroleum products are moved in
40,000 to 60,000 dead weight ton ships.
Often these ships and even larger cargo
carriers cannot be filled to capacity because
of the 42-foot channel. This requires the
ships to make an additional stop at another
port to be loaded to full capacity or “top-
off”’. The proposed 50" channel will allow
larger ships to call on the port and existing
ships to be loaded to capacity. This will
lower the cost of shipping bulk goods. It is
estimated that the 50" channel will produce
an average annual savings of over $150 mil-
lion in the export and import of goods.
Failure to complete the previously autho-
rized 50" channel and make other improve-
ments can result in the loss of bulk cargos
to other ports.

Over 97 million cubic yards of material
must be dredged during the next 20 years
from Baltimore Harbor channels alone. The
State of Maryland, if it is to deepen and
maintain the Ports’ channels, must assume
responsibility for developing a long term
plan for spoils management including
methods and sites for disposal. This must
include material which is expected to be
generated by private projects. The State has
constructed the Hart/Miller Islands disposal
site to handle the 50" channel project. This
project will cost over $60 million and
accommodate approximately 55% of the
total harbor dredge material. However,
methods to accommodate the remaining
45% of dredge material expected over the
next twenty years must also be identified by
the MPA. This is especially critical for long
range maintenance dredging and for private
projects. The MPA should not only explore
a wide range of alternatives including over-
boarding clean material, recycling, creating
wetlands and developing upland sites but

~must also identify funding techniques for

both the public and private sector.



100
